episode.title: Arizonans for Official English v. Arizona

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument now in Number 95-974, Arizonans for Official English and Robert D. Park v. Arizona.

Mr. Zall, and let me request of you, Mr. Zall, and also of your colleague that the Court is very interested in hearing a full discussion of the issues relating to standing, mootness, and jurisdiction, so we hope you'll devote a substantial part of your arguments to that.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
This First Amendment facial overbreadth case involves a Government employee who wanted to write her official documents in a language her supervisor did not understand.
Even if her choice of language on the job was speech, which is was not, it was the Government's speech, not hers.
Under Capital Square, Government runs no risk of a First Amendment violation when it restrains its own speech.
Official English statutes, which are simply restraints on the Government's own speech, do not violate the First Amendment.
It's a political choice.
One point was not treated sufficiently in the briefs.
Last term in County Commissioners v. Umbehr, a Government contractors case, the Court said that the Government's interest in speech depends on the speaker's proximity to Government.
The closer to Government, the greater the Government's interest.

Umbehr described a speech spectrum ranging from private citizens, in whose speech the Government has little interest, to Government employees, whose closeness to Government means that the Government is very interested in their speech.

Government contractors fell somewhere in between Government employees, who had the closest relationship to Government, and other speakers with less close relationships, and though not said in Umbehr, since Government is actually closest to itself, Government speech, the Government speech cases would be... would place very high on the Umbehr speech spectrum, beyond--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Zall, this particular Government, at least the Attorney General, long before this case was decided by the district court said that the constitutional provision in Arizona did not prohibit the use of a language other than English where necessary to assure the fairness and effectiveness of the delivery or services to members of the public.
Why didn't that end this controversy?

The then plaintiff, the sole plaintiff in effect got all the relief that she sought, which was the assurance that she wouldn't be fired if she used a language other than English where necessary to assure the fair delivery of her service.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Your Honor, we agree with the Attorney General's opinion as to its construction of Article XXVIII on the First Amendment grounds.
We also agree that the Attorney General appropriately considered equal protection matters.
Our concern is that the Attorney General's opinion relied on a case which, subsequent to the opinion, this court vacated on mootness, and that was an equal protection issue.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Did the Attorney General withdraw that opinion as the official interpretation of the State's executive?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: It did not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So that's the law as far as the executive's... as far as official Government in Arizona is concerned, so my question is, why didn't this case end?
Wasn't it moot at that point?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Your Honor, I believe the plaintiffs in the case said that the next Attorney General could issue another opinion and the Attorney General's opinion was not binding on the courts, therefore they felt that they still had a viable case, and the district court disagreed with the Attorney General's interpretation and decided not to abide by it, as did the Ninth Circuit.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, is... it's not a question of what the district court independently might think the law was.
The question was, was the plaintiff at any risk of losing her job when the official interpretation, the State's interpretation, was that what she was doing was all right?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I think the answer to that question is she was at no risk of losing her job, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, didn't... what controversy was left, then, if she was at no risk of losing her job?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I believe, Your Honor, that although that was... that's the correct interpretation, she did not agree with that and asked the court on a slightly different ground, which is that she was not... excuse me.

The district court handed down a decision on a slightly different ground, which is that although she was not at risk from losing her job, it decided this was a facial overbreadth case and felt somehow there were some risk to other Government employees who were not before the court.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What basis would there have been for that?
I mean, the Attorney General's statement of State law was not a statement which was peculiar to her.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I think that's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So the district court was wrong, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I believe the district court was wrong, Your Honor.
This never should have been a facial overbreadth--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So at that point the case was certainly moot, even if we make the assumption that there was a case or controversy at some point.
And it probably became moot when Ms. Yniguez left her State employment, I would have thought, at the very least.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Your Honor, the central point of mootness is whether this Court's decision can affect the legal rights of the parties before it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, who do you represent, exactly, here?
Is it that organization that helped put it on the ballot--

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --and a Mr. Park?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And how is it that they have standing in this case at this juncture?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Petitioners have standing because the lower court decisions affected their legal rights.
They have legal rights created by the State.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What kind of rights does your organization have, AOC, or whatever it is?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: AOE--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You assume that it's some kind of legislative standing for them?
What is it you're arguing for that would give them standing?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --In footnote 17 of Diamond v. Charles the Court noted that a State may create interest the invasion of which would give standing in Federal court.
That's exactly what we have here.
The State created an interest in petition--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I would have thought Diamond v. Charles would require us to say that the organization does not have legislative standing.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Your Honor, Diamond v. Charles as I read it is predicated on the ability to create and enact a legally enforceable code, citing Snapp.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But how does that give the organization here standing, Arizonans for Official English?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Well, that goes back to the standing question for organizations, Your Honor.
There are two ways that we have standing.
One is the invasion of our ability to go into State court.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, once the thing is adopted by the voters, I don't see what standing that organization has to litigate in Federal court.
Along that same line, how is your organization any different from any citizen in the State of Arizona?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Your Honor, the statute... the citizens' suit provision in Article XXVIII, section 4 permits any person or organization doing business in Arizona to enforce Article XXVIII in State court.
That would not, in and of itself, give standing.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, why wouldn't that just be a State law cause of action?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: It is a State--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I mean, how do you get to Federal court?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Because the Federal court decision eliminated that State court right.
It would be the equivalent of our having any other State interest, State granted interest which the Federal court's action then eviscerated.
We would have the right to come to Federal court and say, we fought hard for that right.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, that part of your answer then seems to me that you're agreeing that you're no different than any other citizen of the State of Arizona.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I think that's not correct, Your Honor.
I think because we are the proponents and we expect... it was our court purpose to get that right under--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but you were just the mechanism for putting something on the ballot.
Unlike a legislature, the voters didn't give any authority to you.
They voted for a measure.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --That's true, Your Honor, but the question--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Would a Senator who sponsors a bill have standing to challenge a court's evisceration of the bill after it's been adopted as a statute--

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --The Senator--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --on the ground that he's... you know, it's my bill.
It was my idea.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, the Senator alone probably not, but the legislative body itself would under Chadha, and I think that that's a situation where--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is that clear that where the courts misinterpret a statute the Congress that passed the statute has standing to challenge the court's interpretation of it?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Not quite at that point, Your Honor.
What Chadha says is, where the executive branch and the challenger both agree that the provision is unconstitutional, Congress was the appropriate body to defend the statute.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but Congress is a standing branch of the Government with ongoing duties and responsibilities, and it was vitally interested in the one-House veto from the standpoint of its institutional capacity.
All your organization did was put something on the ballot.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Your Honor, the same situation applies in Arizona, where the Arizona constitution, Article IV, provides that the voters themselves have the right to an initiative, and this is a matter in which this would affect the voters' right of initiative.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Mr.--
--Is your claim... I'm sorry.
Go ahead.
I had one.
Are you claiming that the Arizona provision therefore creates Article III standing for any Arizona citizen in a Federal court?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I'm suggesting that in certain limited circumstances the invasion of the right would give someone standing to complain about it, and the difference is--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But what is the invasion of the right which would be in any way different from an invasion which any citizen simply as a citizen could claim?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Your Honor, the invasion of the right is the elimination of the right.
That goes to the injury question, the prudential question.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, in... then I think what you're saying is that any citizen could have Article... would have Article III standing.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I don't believe so, Your Honor, because the individual interest... t he individual injury to each citizen is so small relative to everyone else that there is no differentiation, but to the initiative proponent, just as in this Court's decision in the Term Limits case, where the State was present, just as the State is present here, the initiative proponents were able to come forward and make their best case.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Because the State was present making the argument on the merits, but here we don't have that.
I think the State is telling us this case is moot, right?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Your Honor, that's the State's position, but lower... in the lower courts they were quite clear on their position on the merits.
It's only when they came to this Court that they brought up once again this issue.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Yes, but this Court is bound by a case or controversy requirement, and the State is acknowledging that that no longer exists.
You did say one thing, Mr. Zall, that puzzled me, and perhaps I misunderstood you.

You said that you were now disabled because the Federal court had eliminated your right, but it was not my understanding that a district court or a court of appeals is a higher authority on a question of Federal constitutional law than, say, the supreme court of Arizona.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Your Honor, I'm sure that's true as to the interpretation of State law, but not necessarily the application of Federal law to State law, but leaving that aside--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Do you think... is the... are the Arizona State courts bound by what the Ninth Circuit thinks Federal constitutional law is?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --I think the courts are split on that, Your Honor.
I know the Arizona position is that they are not bound, but there are cases--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So that's... since that is the position of the State courts in your State, then nothing has been eliminated by anything that a district court or the court of appeals said.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, as to us, and this goes to our own unique situation and why we're different from everyone else--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Unless the plaintiffs can sue in Federal court.

I mean, I assume what you're worried about is that any State employee who doesn't want to abide by this provision would simply bring a 1983 action in State court... in Federal court, and the Federal district court at least would be bound by the determination of the court of appeals here and would apply the opinion that you don't agree with.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --That's our concern, Your Honor under--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If we were to find that your organization does not have standing here, I guess... and for that reason dismiss the case, I guess the consequence would be that the court of appeals judgment would stand, because you just came in at this last stage, right?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
We attempted to intervene.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You attempted to intervene, but you were not a party in the court of appeals.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: We were a party in the court of appeals Your Honor.
In the 939 Fed. 2d opinion, Yniguez won.
We were permitted--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But there were other parties on your side of the case in the court of appeals.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Well, because of a fairly bizarre application of 2403(b), we were the only group that the court designated as a party.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: You were not a party in the district court.
The district court denied your motion to... your post judgment motion to intervene, is that right?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And you didn't seek to enter the litigation before the judgment in the district court.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And was the reason that you didn't because you thought that the State was going to defend the provisions?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
That's what the Ninth Circuit found also, and we did receive those assurances.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What about after the Attorney General took a position with which I gather you disagreed about the narrowness of the provision?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Your Honor, in the district court the State's position was completely... was the same as ours.
They argued the constitutionality.

They argued one additional factor, which was the Eleventh Amendment, and ultimately the court, the district court accepted their Eleventh Amendment argument but rejected their constitutional argument.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Get back to the point I'm concerned about.
If you don't have standing here, the decision, at least of the district court, remains in effect, isn't that right, because you... your standing has nothing to do with the district court judgment.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Unless this Court vacates it, or--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why would we vacate?
They were proper parties.
If we take the ground that you're not a proper party here, nor were in the court of appeals, the district court judgment would still stand.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Your Honor, if--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I assume.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --I'm sorry.

If... since the State attempted to intervene in the district court level under 2403(b) and was reversed, I believe that the appeal, at least of that order, is still properly before this Court, and I think that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I thought the Governor was a party in the district court, wasn't he?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --The Governor was, Your Honor.
She... and--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And the Governor thought the constitutional provision was invalid, I understand, Governor Mofford.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --She did, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And the Attorney General said it's not enforceable in the circumstances that Yniguez said it was, so it seems to me that there's no controversy before the Court if you have no standing.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Your Honor, if we have no standing, and the argument is that the district court's opinion stands, then you will have in essence private constitutional review.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, under our Bankcorp decision it seems to me that even though we were to conclude you have no standing, that does not mean we would simply dismiss the petition for certiorari if we find that there was a defect further below, that there was... either controversy either had become moot, or there was no case or controversy in the first place.
This Court would then have the authority to vacate the opinions below, I believe.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I believe that's also the position of the States in its briefs, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why would we vacate the opinion below?
That is to say, I can see if you were the only party before the Ninth Circuit and you don't have standing, then we'd vacate that, I guess.
There was no controversy because they weren't parties.

But in the district court, prior to Ms. Yniguez leaving her job, the district court reached its decision and then the other party to the case, the Governor, decided not to appeal, so there was no appeal, and therefore the district court decision stays in place.
I suppose--
--So why--
--Yes.
I suppose there is a question, though, which I had already asked you, about whether there was even--
--That's right.
That's right.
--a controversy at the district court.
That--
--because the Governor took the same position as Ms. Yniguez.
Exactly.
Whether there was ever a controversy.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Your Honor, I think there's also a question--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So could you go back... I mean, I'm quite interested in your response to Justice O'Connor's question.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --As to whether there was ever a controversy in the district court, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, because that would seem to be determinative, wouldn't it, about whether or not we vacated, assuming you lose all the other points, the district court decision or just vacated the court of appeals decision, so I think your response would be important on that.
And of course if you left that in place you could review the matter in some other case.
I mean, you're not deprived of constitutional review.

Was there ever a point when the Governor was adverse to the plaintiff in this case, and there was one statement that the Governor said that she would comply with the constitutional amendment, and she expected every other State official to do the same.
Now, was there ever any adversary contest in the district court, or did we have a friendly lawsuit throughout?
Was there ever any point where the Governor took the position before the district court, I am defending the constitutionality of this State constitutional provision?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I believe that was the position of the State throughout the district court--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: State meaning government, because it's hard to tell who is the State in this case.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --I'm sorry.
The State was a party until December 21, 1988, when it was dismissed on Eleventh Amendment grounds, and then the complaint was refiled without the State.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But would... and then the Governor, as the chief executive officer of the State, did she ever take a position in opposition to the plaintiff--

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I believe--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --in the litigation?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Yes.
I believe the answer is yes.
In the litigation the Governor's position, as articulated by the Attorney General, who was representing all the parties in that--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Including the Governor.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Including the Governor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but--

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: But before--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --I had thought that they had conflicting positions.

I had thought that the Governor indicated that she agreed with the district court that it's unconstitutional, but that the Attorney General said that it would not be enforced against Yniguez, but even if we take those two combined, it seems to me that there's no controversy.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Your Honor--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: There's no... at least there's no threat.
There's no threat to the employee.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --The Attorney General's position was, both prior to the opinion in the litigation, that there was no threat to the employee, and at the point of the opinion said, in essence, there's no--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So at that point where was the controversy?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Since this is a First Amendment case, Your Honor, what's concerning me is that the Court is very solicitous towards concerns of chilling First Amendment speech, and because the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You're chilled if there's a threat.
You're not chilled if there's no threat.
I mean, that's... don't you need a threat to be chilled?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --I think Your Honor's question is whether you would need a realistic threat to be chilled.
I think a perceived threat which chills speech might be--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You have an unrealistic threat--

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --that chills you?
Wouldn't an unrealistic threat produce an unrealistic chill?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --I think it would, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask another question about the status of the case?
I take it the defendants never filed an answer, or did they?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Defendants did file an answer, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Including the defendant Catherine Eden?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor, I think I misspoke.
I believe the defendants did not file an answer in the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Was--

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --They filed a motion to dismiss.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --One of the defendants was Catherine Eden, the director of the Department and so forth and so on.
Was her position ever made known formally of record?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Other than the Attorney General's representation, her own personal position, Your Honor?
I don't think so.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Can you tell me, is the director of this employee's Department bound by the Attorney General's interpretation of the act?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Although the Attorney General's opinion is not binding on the courts--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is it binding on this agency?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --The director of the Department of Administration?
I don't know the answer to that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Not much use being an Attorney General, I would guess, if your opinions on the law are not binding on the other executive officers.
You might as well not have one.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I believe the Attorney General's opinion power as under ARS 41-193 (A) is in the statute, but the courts have decided that they're not binding on--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh, they're not binding on the courts, I've no doubt about... let me ask about damages.
Did the district court award nominal damages?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, following the Ninth Circuit en banc opinion.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Following the Ninth Circuit en banc opinion--

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --but not originally?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And the Ninth Circuit used as the basis for its jurisdiction once Yniguez was no longer employed and the case would otherwise be moot the fact that... what?
Although the district court had not... although she... had she asked for nominal damages?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Not specifically, but she had asked for all other relief.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: All other relief.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Which is what the Ninth Circuit--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And the Ninth Circuit en banc sent it back saying that you could have awarded nominal damages, even though the court had not awarded nominal damages.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.
It also said that Ms. Yniguez--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But since it hadn't awarded nominal damages, why wasn't the case moot once she left employment?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --The Ninth Circuit felt that she had--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It could--

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --the right to ask for nominal damages, and that was enough.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Well, that's... so retroactively the Ninth Circuit said go back and get nominal damages and that will retroactively keep the case alive.
Is that what the Ninth Circuit did?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I think what they're asking is that she could ask for it.
It was the request and the expectation rather than the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But the case was over below.
She had gotten her relief.
The relief did not include nominal damages.
The only relief it got was injunction against enforcing this against her in the future.
Then she leaves the State employ.
There's nothing left to the case, right?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Actually, there was no injunction issued, either.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well... just a declaratory judgment.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Just a declaratory judgment.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So that she would know that she wouldn't be threatened, or chilled, unrealistically or realistically, whatever.
[Laughter]
Right?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: The court felt that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And the Ninth Circuit said, however, although there's nothing here that... once you've left employment there's really nothing at issue any more, there could be something at issue if the district court had granted you nominal damages, and we will remand to the district court to have the district court, if it wishes, grant you nominal damages, whereupon, retroactively, our jurisdiction on the appeal will be valid.
Is that what the district court of appeals did?
You can object to the question as leading.
[Laughter]
Chief Justice, I'm leading him where he doesn't want to go.
I think--
--he wants to have the case here, but I don't see how it's here.
That's characteristic of all leading questions.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --I think, given the context, my proper answer should be yes, but I think my answer's actually no, Your Honor, because I think what it was suggesting was that in the peculiar circumstances before the court at the time there were still legal rights between the parties before the court, which it had made parties, which could be determined by the court on the facts in front of it.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes, but there was no legal right to damages, was there?
I mean, the Ninth Circuit... apart from everything else that Justice Scalia recited, the Ninth Circuit was also wrong in suggesting that she would have a right to nominal damages, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: I think under the Eleventh Amendment that's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask you what... in your judgment what we should do with the case?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: If--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You must have a position.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You represent a client before us.
[Laughter]
And I'm curious to know what your position, independent of all the questions that have been asked of you--
--Perhaps we could have it printed in a casebook on jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
turn.text: Obviously, our preference is to have the Court decide the merits, since we believe that the rights of petitioners and respondents would be determined at that point, but if the Court finds that this case was moot, either from the start there was no subject matter jurisdiction, then clearly we would ask the Court to vacate all the way down.
If there are no other questions, I'd like to reserve--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Zall.
Mr. Pohlman, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

When the State of Arizona determined in its exercise of it sovereign judgment that it would not join in the petition for certiorari in this case and that it would not appeal the final judgment in Ms. Yniguez' favor for nominal damages in the district court, this case became one without an Article III case for controversy and should have concluded.
We would ask that this Court dismiss the petition because the petitioners lack standing to maintain this action in this Court.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I certainly agree with that, but why didn't it suddenly become nonexistent as soon as the district court entered a judgment that didn't include nominal damages and the petitioner later, and before the appeal, resigned from her State employment?
Why didn't it become moot then?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: It wasn't moot for a number of reasons, Justice Scalia, one of which is that there was a final unappealed judgment in favor of the... Ms. Yniguez against Governor Mofford, so that judgment was binding and final long before she left State employment.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, why was there a case or controversy in the district court, please?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: In the district court there was a case or controversy initially because, as a factual matter, the district court found that Ms. Yniguez had suffered an injury in fact in that she... her First Amendment rights had been chilled.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, the Government... the Governor agreed that the proposition was invalid.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: The Governor agreed after the judgment, Your Honor, Justice O'Connor, that it was invalid.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, there was never... there was never an answer on the merits, was there?
There was just a motion to dismiss by Arizona.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: There... I don't recall, Justice O'Connor, whether there was an answer.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Isn't that right?
Isn't that all there was?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: I don't recall if there was or not.
I tend to believe there was an answer because the case went on for so long below, and actually went to trial.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But at any point in the litigation did either the Governor or the Attorney General indicate that your client would be disciplined for using Spanish?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: There was... Justice Kennedy, there was no specific indication.

However, there was a finding that Governor Mofford intended to enforce the article, that she expected Government employees to enforce the article and to comply with the article, and that therefore Ms. Yniguez had a chilling effect on her First Amendment rights that was caused by Governor Mofford, and that's found in the appendix to the petition for certiorari at pages 102 and 103.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What was the basis for that finding?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: It was Governor Mofford's outspoken indication that she intended to enforce Article XXVIII, and that she expected Government employees to comply.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But in view of the Attorney General's opinion, enforcement of it does not seem to have a realistic prospect of any effect on Ms. Yniguez.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: First, Mr. Chief Justice, Ms. Yniguez did not have the benefit of that particular Attorney General's opinion until some 3-1/2 months after this litigation was commenced, so for that 3-1/2 month period of time, her rights were obviously chilled.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but if they were chilled for 3-1/2 months and then all of a sudden unchilled, the lawsuit doesn't go ahead on the basis of what was the case earlier, does it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: It doesn't, Mr. Chief Justice.
However, in the case of the Attorney General's opinion below, that opinion was found to be nonbinding.
The district court judge recognized that the... a different Attorney General may well have a different opinion.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Nonbinding on whom?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: The... it was not binding on any court.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Ah.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: It was binding--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But the court wasn't... but the claim wasn't that the court was going to prosecute her.

The claim was that someone representing the State, the Governor, the Attorney General, or her supervisor was going to bring some action against her, and the opinion, I presume, was binding on those people, possibly with the exception of the Governor, but it was binding on the others, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --My understanding, Justice Souter, is that it would be binding on those lower administrative employees, including Catherine Eden, who was one of the defendants who was--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So that leaves the Governor, and isn't it also the case that prior to the district court judgment, in any even prior certainly to the expiration of the appeal period, the Governor herself had gone on record in her own right as saying that she thought it was proper to use English if necessary to discharge one's duties in a reasonable way.
Isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --In the record, Justice Souter, the Governor always said that she would enforce the article until such time as the judgment was entered by the district court.
At that time, she indicated she did not intend to appeal, but she also thought it was--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but didn't she at some point, and I'm not positive of what this moment was, didn't she also indicate, quite apart from her general position that the amendment should be enforced, that she believed it was proper for a State employee to use some non-English language if that was reasonable in the discharge of the employee's duties?
Didn't she say that?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --That's not my understanding, Justice Souter.
That language was included in the Attorney General's opinion, which was in January, of course, after the lawsuit had been initiated, and--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But well before judgment was reached in the district court.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, before judgment was reached and before trial, and at the trial the district court judge determined that, notwithstanding that Attorney General's opinion, given what Governor Mofford had said in public, and given the immediacy of the chilling effect on Ms. Yniguez' rights, that there was, in fact, an injury in fact to her, notwithstanding that opinion, and that is why he entered the declaratory relief--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Is your view that there should be no vacation of any decision, not the Ninth Circuit's, and if that is your view, how can, at least with respect to the Ninth Circuit when the plaintiff was no longer in the State's employ and before the Ninth Circuit reached its judgment, how can you defend keeping that judgment on the books?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --Justice Ginsburg, I think what we do is, we look at the Bonner Mall Partnership case, and we find that vacatur is an equitable doctrine.
If we look at the equities as to what occurred first in the district court, there was no appeal by the Governor.
It was a final unappealed judgment long before Ms. Yniguez left Government service.
Therefore, that judgment, in our view, cannot be vacated under Bonner Mall Partnership.

But if you look at the equities with respect to the Ninth Circuit, at the time that that judgment was entered, Mr. Zall's group and the Attorney General sought to intervene for purposes of taking an appeal of the judgment at that time.
Ms. Yniguez had no reason at that juncture to appeal her claim for nominal damages because the district court said we will not allow this judgment to be appealed.
No one has an interest to appeal it.
It is going to stop right here.
And so all that was on appeal--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, how can a district court prevent someone from appealing?
I can see how the court of appeals could say there is no interest, but what did the district... did the district court enter some sort of an order that they couldn't appeal?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
What the district court did was to deny the motions of Mr. Zall's group, Arizonans for Official English, and the Attorney General, to intervene for the purpose of taking an appeal.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What you're saying is no one who was then in the lawsuit was interested in appealing.
We had the plaintiff and the Governor, and that's it, right?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And it was only after final judgment was entered with respect to those two parties that additional people asked to come in, one AOE and the other the Attorney General.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And the district court said no, I deny your motion, your post judgment motion to intervene.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: That is exactly--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And the first thing that the court of appeals did was to reverse that denial as to AOE, right?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --That is correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And then what the district... what the court of appeals did concerning the Attorney General I'm not altogether clear.
Was the Attorney General, in your view, a party in the case at the appellate level?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: I... yes and no, and the reason I answer it that way, Justice Ginsburg, is because they were permitted to intervene under... and I would share Mr. Zall's view that it's kind of a bizarre application of 28 U.S.C. 2403(b), but the Attorney General is permitted to intervene for the purpose of arguing the constitutionality of the amendment.

That statute provides that the Attorney General may do so or the State may do so and has all the rights and obligations of a party, but they're not exactly a party, although they have all rights and obligations, including the right to petition for certiorari to this Court.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But the State's position, as I understand it, is that the case became moot when the plaintiff left the State's employ, and that happened before the Ninth Circuit's judgment.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, that's the State's position of the day, although their position has never been consistent throughout this litigation.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Whose has?
Yes, that's for sure.
[Laughter]
Mr. Pohlman, I don't understand why you said it was okay for your client not to appeal the denial of nominal damages.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Justice--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: She was the plaintiff.
The Governor was the defendant.
The district court denied her nominal damages against the Governor.
Now, to be sure, the Governor then said, I don't want to appeal, but why couldn't your client have said, but I do?
I have been denied nominal damages.
I think I was entitled to them, and I want an appeal.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --Justice Scalia, she could have appealed at that juncture.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I thought Yniguez never even asked for nominal damages in the district court.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: We did not ask for--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: For such other relief.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --We did not ask for nominal damages in the district court at the initial phase.
We asked for all... anything that might be just and equitable in premises in a traditional addendum clause.
In the Ninth Circuit, that is--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, actually, you put in zero zero on dollar amounts, did you not?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --With respect to damages?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: I don't recall that being in the judgment.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Even if such other relief as may seem just and proper... are they still using that language in Arizona complaints +/?

that's good enough to keep... to leave the question open for the district court, but when the district court at the end of the case does not grant nominal damages, then it seems to me you've got a much different question.
For the Ninth Circuit to send the thing back and say you could have asked for nominal damages seems extraordinary.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, they are still using that language in Arizona, and what occurred, really, is the Ninth Circuit said, because we had requested at the time that if it goes back, and if there ever is an appeal from the judgment on the merits, which there had not been previously, there had only been an appeal that... a procedural question of whether or not Mr. Zall and his group and the Attorney General could intervene, because up to that point in time Ms. Yniguez had a declaratory judgment in her favor.
She had no reason, as long as the actual judgment was not in jeopardy, to go and ask the district court to spend the time to get $1 in nominal damages.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: When she did ultimately cross-appeal... she did ultimately cross-appeal after the Ninth Circuit reversed the district court's intervention order, correct?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Now, what was the basis for her cross-appeal.
What was she asking on the cross-appeal?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: She was asking for a judgment of nominal damages in her favor based upon the rights that she had... had been found to have been violated in the district--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: On the cross-appeal, but since she had made that claim only on cross-appeal, if AOE's appeal was improper because it's an improper party, then her cross-appeal fails because her cross-appeal was only derivative of the main appeal, isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --We don't believe so, Justice Kennedy, and the reason is this.
The State at that point in time was still in the case as an intervenor under 2403(b).

In fact, the State actively opposed the nominal damages cross-appeal, filed its own appeal with respect to procedural aspects of the case, and later, after the Ninth Circuit remanded for the purpose of award of nominal damages, or at least entered its decision, the State expressly waived its right, or its immunity under the Eleventh Amendment.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: When did the nominal damages cross-appeal occur?
I'm not clear on that.
When did that occur?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Within 30 days of the first appeal on the merits, by either of the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Could we go back just one step?
We have... was this a 1983 action in the district courts--

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --Yes--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --Section 1983?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --Yes, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And have we not held in cases like Will v. Michigan that States and State officials like the Governor are not persons under 1983?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: For purposes of damages?

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: I think--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So how could the district court ever, under a 1983 suit, assess even nominal damages against the State?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --It's my understanding that under the Ex parte Young doctrine there can be an award of nominal damages, and I don't have the case before me.

I would be happy to submit a letter brief, Justice O'Connor, if that would assist the Court, but in any event what occurred was the nominal damages were awarded in the face of an express waiver of immunity by the State of Arizona.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Where do we find that express waiver in the record?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: That would be on page 32 of our appendix in Ms. Yniguez' brief, which is the letter from the Attorney General, at that point in time Grant Woods.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: In your brief on the merits here?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Yes.
Our appendix in the brief on the merits, Justice O'Connor.
And it's for that reason that we believe that we properly have damages awarded for $1 and proper damages were awarded.
The judgment in fact was entered in November of last year, and that can be found at page 211 of the joint appendix.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Pohlman, I take it you are recognizing that the Attorney General was a proper party adverse to you in the court of appeals.
I gather that from footnote 10 on page 23 of your brief.
You seem to say there that while you have consistently argued that AOE has no standing, that doesn't require vacating the Ninth Circuit's opinion because the State has standing.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: That's quite accurate.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Now, if that's so, the State's position here is that the case is moot, at least when the plaintiff left the employ of the State of Arizona.
When mootness occurs in between the district court and the court of appeals, isn't Munsingwear the rule that we follow?
The State is an appellant.
It says, we have no responsibility for the plaintiff leaving the employ.
We didn't get a chance to get appellate review, so the district court decision has to be vacated.
If the State is legitimately a party, as you seem to concede on appeal, doesn't that follow?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, that would follow normally under Munsingwear if, in fact, there had been no judgment for nominal damages, that had not been appealed and had actually been expressly waived, that judgment by the State, and they had opposed that all the way through the Ninth Circuit and then decided after that judgment was entered to eschew a judicial review of that.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So you're hanging everything on that $1 of nominal damages.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: No, Justice Ginsburg, I would not say that.
I would say that that is one of the aspects of this case upon which we hang our hat for purposes of case or controversy.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, what else is there?
Let's leave out the $1 nominal damages.
We have a case that's a perfectly good final judgment.
We have an appellant that you concede is a proper appellant, the State.
The case becomes moot through no... nothing that the appellant has done between the district court and the court of appeals.
Isn't our normal practice in that situation to vacate the district court's decision?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Absent the nominal damages under normal circumstance, Justice Ginsburg, I think that would be the case.

However, here we have a First Amendment overbreadth case, and to add to some of the procedural dilemma below at the time the suggestion of mootness was made by the Solicitor General who replaced the original Solicitor General in the case, we had at that time pending an appeal by State Senator Jaime Gutierrez, whose appeal unfortunately got lost in the docketing system of the Ninth Circuit, and it was agreed--
[Laughter]

It was agreed between the parties, and we can find this in the joint appendix, but it was agreed between the parties at that point in time, that being the State and Ms. Yniguez and AOE, that if the matter were to be remanded for consideration on the merits, then the appeal of Senator Gutierrez would also be joined with it.
That never occurred for reasons which are--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And what was his standing?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --Senator Gutierrez was a State legislator at the time.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: He had the same standing as the petitioner does here, in other words.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: I would say he had much greater standing in the sense that--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: He voted for this measure?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --Senator Gutierrez would not have voted for this, Justice Stevens.
He's bilingual and a State legislature who often communicated with his constituents--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In other words, he voted against it.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --I would expect he voted against it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So what... again, what is his standing?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: A State legislator whose conduct was threatened by Article XXVIII in that he routinely, as many State legislatures... legislators do, communicated with his constituents during the performance of Government business in languages other than English.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Your position, Mr. Pohlman, is that AOE has no standing here, I take it.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And where does that leave people who vote and perhaps organize to get a referendum passed.
Typically the Arizona constitutional convention, one of the reasons for referendum was that you couldn't get something through the legislature because of special interests, so let the people do it.
The referendum passes, and the Governor and the Attorney General hypothetically say, you know, we don't like this thing, we're not going to defend it.
Who then defends the action?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Once it gets to that point in time, Mr. Chief Justice, I don't think anyone defends the action.
I think it is the obligation of the State to defend that action and indeed, they did in this case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if they don't, though?
I mean, they say we don't like the bill.
We're just going to let it go.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: In that event I would suggest to Mr. Chief Justice that the voters who passed the initiative would probably change the administration when they next went to the polls.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But there's no way for anybody to come in and defend the initiative if the Governor and the Attorney General won't do it.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: In our view, that would be the case.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, there is a citizens suit provision, and the citizens can sue in State court to enforce something that's been validly passed under the very terms of the provision that was passed, is that not so?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: There is, indeed, an enforcement provision in the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Anybody who claims to be adversely affected.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --Anyone who desires, I believe, Your Honor, to enforce the provisions.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So there is a citizens suit provision.
Somebody can come into court and raise it.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Your Honor, I'm not so sure that a citizens suit provision in an initiative like this would give any citizen of the State of Arizona then carte blanche under Article III to challenge a declaration by the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I guess we don't worry about Article III in State court actions.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --You're right, in State court they could challenge it, and that challenge would still be viable today.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Exactly.

Well, but where the question is based on the Chief Justice's inquiry, followed by Justice O'Connor, is we're assuming the State officials do not enforce the act, and Justice O'Connor points out that the initiative does have a citizens suit provision allowing a citizen to enforce the act.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: That's accurate, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But the citizens suit provision may come up against a barrier if there's previously been an action in the Federal court where the Governor and the Attorney General are enjoined from enforcing it, which went by default, so the Attorney General and the Governor would then have a perfectly good defense to the citizens suit provision of res judicata as a result of the Federal action.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, I think that may be true with respect to the Attorney General and the Governor.
My understanding of the enforcement provision is it was directed at administrative employees or anyone that... a citizen or person doing business in the State--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And I guess there was no injunction here.
A declaratory judgment, right?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --It was simply a declaratory judgment.
There was no injunction, injunctive relief granted, Justice--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Mr. Pohlman, may I go back to Justice Ginsburg's question going to the issue of whether we should vacate the district court judgment?
Would this be a position that you would espouse, that at the conclusion of the district court action, neither of the parties before the district court appealed.
It is quite true that there was then an intervention, and ultimately in the Ninth Circuit the State came in.
The Attorney General came in under the statute for the purposes of defending the constitutionality of the State act.
But the Attorney General at that point was in there only on a kind of conditional basis.

He was only in there saying, if we're going to have an appeal, then I'm here under the statute representing, in effect, the State to uphold the constitutionality of the act if I can, but I'm not an independent appealing party, and the State and the Governor are not independent appealing parties.
Given that interpretation, would it, even on our normal equitable vacatur rules, be appropriate not to vacate the district court judgment, because the parties who could have appealed in fact did not.
The parties who presumably would suffer from leaving the judgment on the books did not, in fact, appeal.
Would that be a... would you espouse that argument for opposing vacating the district court order?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --I would espouse that argument to oppose vacating the district court order, exactly.
Justice, Souter, I believe that the Attorney General, though, had a slightly different position insofar as the Ninth Circuit is concerned.
The Attorney General actively sought to reinsert himself as a party for the purposes of pursuing the appeal with or without AOE when they were in the district court.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But that was... wasn't that after the appeal period had run?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it was not.
They appealed within the time frame that was necessary in order to... had they been granted leave to intervene.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Oh, so--
--That was the position that you took in this footnote that I read.
You recognized the standing of the Attorney General as a proper party.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, if that's the case, then, then the Attorney General was not in only on the limited basis that my suggestion gave him, so I suppose if you accept his standing as a party at that point, and you take the position that he should have been allowed in, period, then I guess the argument for vacating is a valid argument.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Justice Souter, we would disagree with that for some of the reasons that have been said before, but in fact, and this goes back again to the ruling by the Ninth Circuit with regard to 2403(b), in fact you're entitled to intervene as the State, not as a party, but with all the rights and obligations of a party at that point in time, and the district court recognized there is no right to intervene at that point, or at least felt that way.

The Ninth Circuit gave them a right which is not contemplated by the statute, which was a defendant standing under 2403(b), and I... and for purposes of your question I'm not so sure that was legally correct, but that was the understanding the State had, that they were in there with defendants--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Mm-hmm.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --And that was the position... they never appealed that particular ruling, and that was the way that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Ah, so that's why they're stuck.
Yes, okay.
Could... I have two questions briefly that I'd like to hear your answer to.
The most important is, I'd like to hear clearly what your answer was to Justice O'Connor's initial question.
I take it in the district court there was a person, the plaintiff, and a defendant, the Governor, who had an argument.
The plaintiff won, and the Governor didn't appeal.
All right, but the question was, was there ever a controversy between them, and the answer to that depends upon whether there was a reasonable threat of prosecution, isn't that right?
That's the case they cited in support of that.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, you pointed to a place in the district court's opinion which says I, the district judge, think there was a reasonable threat of prosecution.
Where in the record do I find the material upon which that conclusion rests?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --You will find the testimony in our appendix attached to our brief on the merits at pages 14 and 15, which is the testimony of Ms. Yniguez concerning her fear that she may be prosecuted, or that there may be a citizens suit based upon the test of Article XXVIII.

You will find the judge's conclusion on page 102a of the appendix to the petition for certiorari, where he finds that in fact Ms. Yniguez has suffered an injury in fact due to the threat of potential disciplinary action by virtue of--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Was Ms. Yniguez... excuse me.
Where do I find what the Governor said, because what he's saying is it's the Governor's statement that leads me to think that the Governor might prosecute her.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --That is in the stipulated facts that are in the joint appendix, I believe.
If not, they may be in our appendix beginning at pages 5 and 6.
I don't have that right in front of me, but I can find that for you, Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Pohlman, I hate to come back to this, but I'm still not clear on it.
After the State came in on the appeal, when did the cross-appeal for the denial of nominal damages occur?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: The cross-appeal for the denial of nominal damages occurred shortly after the first appeal on the merits was ever filed by any intervenor, and that was after the case had been remanded, following the decision on the suggestion of--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --It was the first--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: After remand, though.
It's after remand.
The original appeal to the Ninth Circuit went up and back down without any claim of nominal damages involved.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --The original appeal was not on the merits, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I understand.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: That's why the cross-appeal we are not entitled to unless there are... we don't need to cross-appeal on the judgment unless there is actually an appeal on the judgment.
There was none until it was remanded.
That's the first time a notice of appeal on the judgment itself was ever filed under Pellegrino v. Nesbit.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Did the stipulation you... as to the facts covering the Governor's position, I thought that stipulation said nothing about the Governor intending to take enforcement actions, just that the Governor intended to comply.
Well, if the Governor intends to comply by herself speaking English, I suppose that wouldn't affect this at all.
Is there anything in the stipulation that says the Governor intends to take enforcement actions against people like Yniguez?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, I don't believe there's anything that says that per se.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: No, I didn't think so.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: In our appendix at page 8 to our brief on the merits some of the stipulations appear.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: In your red brief?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: This is in your red brief?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice, in the red brief.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Page 8?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Page 8 of our appendix shows some of the stipulations pertaining to what occurs in the disciplinary process.
The testimony below was Ms. Yniguez had seen people disciplined before, that she understood that she was expected to comply--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Disciplined under this statute?

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --Not under this statute, no.
People were disciplined for failing to follow the laws of the State or the constitution of the State--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, that's scarcely surprising.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: --That they would be disciplined for that, and that's what we agreed, Mr. Chief Justice.
It is scarcely surprising.
That's why she was in fear of her job.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but the question is, did the enactment of this law put her in fear of her job.

turn.speaker: robert_h_pohlman
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Pohlman
turn.text: Yes, it did, and that is precisely what the district court found, that she had a reasonable belief that she may be disciplined if she in fact spoke something other than English on the job.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Pohlman.
Mr. Zall, you have 5 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: barnaby_w_zall
turn.label: Mr. Barnaby W. Zall
